displayed_text: Patient: She injected me with something. Family Member: No. No. Doctor: You’ll continue on your hormone shots every three months for the rest of your life. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so I’ll set that visit up for sure. Huh, and then, huh, hopefully within the next couple of weeks we’ll be able to figure out where you are and you can get started on the abiraterone. Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them? Doctor: No. You should not. You’re done. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re going to try a new drug, huh, that’s quite expensive, and we have to just be able to figure out if we can get it for you. Patient: Okay. Family Member: I appreciate it. Right. Patient: And how would I find out?

Patient: …when we make the decision, we’re going to have to weigh it on what what you’re telling us. Uh so you kind of know where I’m coming from. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: Um what is where you’re coming from at this point? What is it that you would suggest? What would - Doctor: I think there are like two broad ways to tackle this. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And at this point in time they are mutually exclusive. And in the future the two are probably going to be combined, but right now they are mutually exclusive. One is to give a radio therapy in the absence of hormone therapy. In other words try give you a non-hormonal treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Such as radiation instead of hormone therapy in order to delay you know the need for hormone therapy. And the other is to start the hormone therapy now and try to combine it with something that may make the hormone therapy work better and longer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: From what I’m hearing and reading between the lines, what I think I’m hearing is that you’d rather try at this point in time something that is a non-hormonal approach such as radiotherapy. And if that is the case, I think that we have an interesting study that I could talk to you about which is using what we call stereotactic radiotherapy. It’s also called CyberKnife because the company that makes the machine that delivers the radiation is called CyberKnife. It’s not a knife; it’s a misnomer. It’s not surgery – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But because the beam of radiation is so precise, it’s called a knife because it’s as precise as a surgeon’s knife. Um if you think that I’m misunderstanding and you really are more open to the hormone therapy option as well or instead of radiation and we also have a trial in that category which is trying to ask the question about whether all hormone therapy in conjunction with a new hormone therapy is better than just the old hormone therapy by itself, the conventional.

Patient: It’s organic medicine. Doctor: Right. You know, we’ve done studies with pomegranates and muscadine grapes, and it sort of extends to that sort of area. Uh, but this again is, uh, experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. So, in that study, we’re looking at how you tolerate it. Uh, what’s the safe dose. Ah, and then, you know, we monitor your disease; that if it’s not getting better, then we move on. If it is improving or not - stable, you can stay with that treatment. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s a phase one. How long does the phase one run for? Uh, because I’m wondering if there are subsequent phases, um but Doctor: So, typically, we treat three men at a one-dose level. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, if they all do well and nothing happens to them, then we treat three more men at a higher dose level, and if nothing happens to them, we go to a higher dose level. Um. Patient: With different people? Doctor: Different people. You know? I would have to check. Again, some of the things we’d have to clarify. Uh, it is – if you’re, let’s say you’re --come in at the second dose level, and you are on it and it, it’s not, the cancer’s not getting worse. Uh, does it make sense to go to the higher dose. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That those men are safe. Or, the fact that your cancer’s not getting worse, why would we change the dose?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The new one and then the OxyContin and then uh your Percocet. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now what’s going on with your Zometa and everything? That’s XGEVA is B___ doing that? Patient: Yeah, yes they are, yes they are. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Because you gave the thing last time on on on my uh calcium. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They highered my calcium level now. Doctor: Let’s see what is this guys’ intake? Yeah it was too low last time.

Patient: Do they have people that know how to put in an IV? Doctor: Yes they do. Well yeah. Family Member: So you think it would be one IV and then all the drugs through the IV? Doctor: Right. Yeah. Family Member: That’s much better. Doctor: That way you don’t get poked five times. If you have five blood draws. Family Member: So how are you feeling about how he is doing? Patient: Disappointed. Doctor: …this is a slight set back that Xtandi didn’t last us as long as I had hoped it would. And honestly I don’t know if that is part of the sort of resistance of BRC - BRCA mutant disease or not. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Nobody does really at this point because very few people have been really treated with Xtandi up front like that. Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then. Doctor: It’s two, it’s two independent things. You are a extremely low risk gist tumor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And and the risk is not determined by the size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s determined by um how rapidly the cells are dividing, so there’s something that’s called a mitosis. Patient: Uh hum.

Family Member: No, we’ve been communicating by email. So we were in Doctor: And you definitely needed to be in the hospital then going closer to home is the right thing. And basically all they needed was to put a catheter in and then that was putting pressure off of your kidney. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: And you know we’ve got our fingers crossed that the hormones are going to be it and adding chemo to the clinical trial would be you know a step above that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The issue for the radiation you know is – one of the things is do we just watch. You know hormones to Dr. ____ that should be enough. Chemo is also going to try to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And on a clinical trial, we don’t know if more is better, but that third drug, if you were to get it, starts to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: If you don’t get it- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - you still have two things that we know kill cancer cells that make people live longer. Patient: Right.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Who become resistant to hormones. Patient: Yeah, you talked about that. Doctor: And one of the things we’re observing is men who have BRCA2 mutation seem to respond really well to getting testosterone. We’re trying to figure out why. We just put in a big grant to kind of study this. So, so, we are about to, uh, have some trials where we’re – one of our trials is, if a guy has a mutation in this and he maybe responds to testosterone and he maybe responds to immune therapy, what if we give him both? Um. So, that’s a trial down the road that’s going to open up, um, probably in the next six months. We can talk more about that. Patient: If you get the grant? Doctor: No, we got that already. Patient: Oh. Doctor: We made a deal with one of the drug companies who makes the immune therapy. Family Member: Well, they are good for something. Doctor: So, my advice right now, we don’t do anything. You’re responding to hormone treatment. Let’s keep going. And, at some point, we don’t know if this has anything to do with BRCA2 or whatever, but at some point, you’re going to become resistant. Everybody does. And, at that point, we, we will discuss what to do next. And, normally, Patient: So --- Doctor: What to do next – I’m sorry – is to give you another hormone therapy. But, in your case, what, what we might do next is consider like, a trial where we use one of these DNA repair blockers. Um. And, we have two of them open right now that you would be eligible for. So. So, you know, the issue with you is I don’t want to talk about those yet because you might respond to hormone therapy for five more years. (laughs) Patient: Yeah. It, it was two hundred and fifty dollars.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: Yeah, good idea. Doctor: I just wont go there. Healthcare Professional: How old is she? Family Member 1: Yeah but the Mother is. Doctor: Yeah, but they’re always into things and we talked about this. Family Member 1: She’s not out of her first trimester. Yeah. Family Member 3: So um, we are worried about him being around the mother that is newly pregnant, she gets her first ultrasound right now. So what do you think? Doctor: Well, they're, you know- Family Member 1: If they ask us for dinner. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, it's sort of you know, you're you're just having social contact is okay. Family Member 1: It’s okay. So he could be around them. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because, obviously, if today’s PSA keeps on going up, we need to look and see what’s going on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And, chances we are going to have to put you on a medication called Zytiga. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. This is a pill. These are pills that have a very good chance of working against the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they will likely shrink the disease and, you know, also lower the PSA, and the good thing is they are likely to work for long periods of time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, the possibility of side effects is a little bit higher. Okay? And usually, those side effects are high blood pressure, leg swelling, low potassium. So, you’re going to have to monitor and stay with the visits because at least for the first few months, we’ll have to monitor you somewhat closer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Once both of us sort of get comfortable, like we did, but you got too comfortable, Doctor: With this medication

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. So it was- Doctor: Wow. That’s quite- you did way more than just a safari. That’s a lot. Family Member: Oh, yeah. Patient: Oh, way, way. Doctor: So how was Cape Town and Johannesburg? Are they nice cities? Family Member: Oh, yes, beautiful. That’s what we said. Everybody always talks about Johannesburg because it kind of reminded you of New York City. And nobody never said anything about Cape Town, and it’s just beautiful, the beaches and everything, like, wow. Doctor: Because they were having a drought there for a long time. Family Member: Yeah. In certain areas, it still is, like the parks, they don’t, they have like, use the, uh, sanitary lotion and stuff on your hands and toilets don’t flush. Doctor: So when you were like in Cape Town. What did you guys do when you were there? Because it’s like summer there now, isn’t it? Family Member: Yeah. It getting to be summer there. Yeah. The weather was very nice. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Did you like go to the beach or you just-?

Patient: I’ll just have one of those for some for some nourishment, water and uh you know I’m, I’m more a fizzy water guy. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So, for, you know, there’s a thing called Ice that’s like. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Like a lot of juice in it. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And there’s something else that my mom gave me, it’s just like a flavoring of a, you know? Doctor: Okay. So you’re, you’re doing what you can. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Let’s get M___. Okay. Yeah. (Door opening) Patient: I’ve been taking my uh you know the Calcitrate. That doesn’t sit well with me. Doctor: Yeah. Why don’t you give it a break? I mean you’ve been on it a while. Let’s give it a break. Patient: Because I, I know what to use it. The one I’ve got is four pills two times twice a day. And when I take the ones at night, man they just.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: How’s your hot flashes? Patient: They come out all the time. (Laughs) Doctor: And urine. Any trouble passing your water? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: Okay. And they didn’t keep you in the hospital. Anything new since I saw you a couple of weeks ago that you want to tell me about? Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No. Doctor: Then why did I bring you back? Patient: You said I have to change, huh, some treatment. Doctor: Let me see what I’ve got here. So you’ve got pain. Let’s put that there. Okay. Any other bumps or lumps that you’ve noted? Any rashes, skin changes?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Terrific. Thank you. Doctor: So I’ll just let you know what the options are. Patient: Thank you. Appreciate it. Doctor: Alright? Patient: Alright. Doctor: Well thank you both for participating. I think you know I think we’ve very appreciative that you know- Patient: Well I hope we learned, we learned something. Maybe. Maybe not. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s a crazy thing to try. So you know it’s not the typical patient that says yeah, I’m, I’m fine. I really appreciate your involvement. Hopefully we’ve got a lot more stuff we can do here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: Yeah, it’s Rite Aid F___. Doctor: Two r’s or one r in F___? Patient: Two. No, it’s just one. Doctor: And do you know the zip for F___? Patient: No. Family Member: Umm, two oh five oh, maybe? (pause) Doctor: F___ five - one five two zero R____. Patient: That’s the one. R____ Doctor: You’ll take that for thirty days, and that will be sent there electronically, so you would be able to pick it up later today. Patient: Okay. Eh, any particular time of day? I’m sure it will come with, just as long as it is around the same time every day. Healthcare Professional: It just says “take it approximately, about the same time each day.” And you can take it with or without food. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that will just cause, uh, a little bit of soft stool.
